title: Why worry about messy data?
body:
One of the biggest problems with all data is the number of errors. Often these errors will not be intentional and may exist simply because situations have changed over many years.

Other times these errors are there because of mistyped data or the tendency to shorten text.

In this module we'll look at:
  • What errors exist in data
  • The data cleaning toolkit
  • Why clean data

title: Open data cleaning – in two minutes
displayTitle: Open data cleaning – in two minutes
body: The ODI’s David Tarrant explains why clean data is important for creating new value, how to go about cleaning up data you find and introduces some helpful tools to support you

title: Data2diamonds: what do we mean by clean open data?
displayTitle: Data2diamonds: what do we mean by clean open data?
body:
Clean data has been processed in order to best suit the intended usage. There are many stages to data preparation and cleaning is one of the most essential.

Clean data should be consistent, free from duplication and ready for machine consumption.

With clean data, it is much easier to combine with other data to reveal insight.

title: Common errors in data
body: There are a number of common errors in data that you should look out for in any dataset.

_items.title: Wrong date formats
_items.body:
Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-Sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes not:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

Additionally some applications (like excel) will guess the format when a data file is loaded, hiding how it is actually written in the file.

The most common error is the mixed use of americn (MM/DD/YYYY) and British (DD/MM/YYYY) format as shown.

_items.title: Multiple representations
_items.body:
Due to the ways that people like to save time in data entry by abbreviating everything, it is very common to end up with several different representations of the same thing.

Additionally, differences in capitalisation, spacing and genders of adjectives can cause issues.

_items.title: Duplicate records
_items.body:
Duplicate records often occur when datasets have been combined or because it was not known there was a record already at the point of entry.

Detecting these can be a little more challenging but no less essential in the cleaning process.

_items.title: Redundant data
_items.body:
Redundant data may have been created in order to provide a certain view on the data, however it is not adding any detail to the data and in most cases can be recalculated from the data itself.

Common occurrences of redundant data include summation (total) rows. To a machine these are data rows and would represent the record with the biggest values.

Other times columns of data have been combined or replicated in order to assist human readability.

_items.title: Broken numerical scales
_items.body:
Numerical values in datasets often use different scales to make it easier for a human to read. For example, in big project budget data the units are often in the millions. Thus 1200000 becomes 1.2m. This can lead to huge errors if even one of these records does not have the correct scale.

One trick is to check for a normal distribution in any numerical data and check the outliers.

_items.title: Mixed ranges
_items.body: Data will often be measured in ranges, e.g. age or salary ranges. In order for a machine to understand these ranges it is important to separate the high and low values.

_items.title: Spelling errors
_items.body:
Obvious when it comes to documents, however when processing data spelling errors are often overlooked.

Don’t forget to run your data through a spell checker and also look for localization/localisation.

title: The data cleaning toolkit
body: Without data, we can’t build information. And without information, there is no new knowledge

_items.title: The data cleaning toolkit
_items.body:
It may be necessary to download and upload your data between many tools for cleaning and processing. Remember to also keep a note of what changes have been made and share these with others. Some of the tools can even help you do this

In this section we look at two of the main tools and their uses:
  • Open refine
  • Excel & similar spreadsheet programmes

_items.title: Open Refine
_items.body:
Open Refine is a powerful software tool designed specifically to deal with messy data. It is a column-based browser that applies facets to the data in order to cleaning fix errors across the entire dataset including:
  • Date formats
  • Multiple representations
  • Duplicate records
  • Redundant data
  • Broken numerical scales
  • Mixed ranges

_items.title: Spreadsheet programmes
_items.body:
Open Refine is the key tool for cleaning data, however sometimes it is easier to fix some errors in a spreadsheet:
  • Spelling errors
  • Redundant data
  • Numerical verification
  • Fixing shifted data

title: What are the benefits of cleaned data?
displayTitle: What are the benefits of cleaned data?
body: Now that we have some knowledge of the tools used to clean data we need to understand why the process can add value to your data use?

_items.title: Prioritise cleaning
_items.body:
If data is not clean then any decisions made could be wrong. This could have a significant impact upon thousands or millions of people's lives.

It has been found that overall the process of preparing data for analysis can take anywhere between 60 and 80% of the time of a data driven project.

So make sure you take care with your data to ensure it is clean and ready for use.

_items.title: Enhance usability
_items.body:
Sharing a clean dataset will enhance the usability of the data. Further tools like Open Refine allow the sharing of the change history, informing people what has been cleaned and how. Making the process open as well as the data adds to the sustainability and trust a user can put in a dataset.

Further there are data cleaning communities emerging which should be supported more actively.

_items.title: Discover insights
_items.body:
Many data cleaning tools, including Open Refine, also provide the ability to combine and enrich datasets.

Without a clean dataset, this process will only make the dataset messier and introduce further errors.

Careful preparation is essential to the success of any data driven project.

title: Why is messy data a problem?
displayTitle: Why is messy data a problem?

_items.text: It cannot be plotted on a chart
It can lead to wrong conclusions

_feedback.correct: Messy data is a problem because it can result in the wrong conclusions being made. This should not prevent the publication or use of the data, however cleaning must be performed.

_incorrect.notFinal: Messy data is a problem because it can result in the wrong conclusions being made. This should not prevent the publication or use of the data, however cleaning must be performed.
_incorrect.final: Messy data is a problem because it can result in the wrong conclusions being made. This should not prevent the publication or use of the data, however cleaning must be performed.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Messy data is a problem because it can result in the wrong conclusions being made. This should not prevent the publication or use of the data, however cleaning must be performed.
_partlyCorrect.final: Messy data is a problem because it can result in the wrong conclusions being made. This should not prevent the publication or use of the data, however cleaning must be performed.

title: What are two of the most useful tools for cleaning data?
displayTitle: What are two of the most useful tools for cleaning data?
body: Which of these pairs of tools are the most useful for cleaning data?

_feedback.correct: Open refine and Excel (or equivalent spreadsheet editors) are two of the most useful tools for cleaning up open data

_incorrect.notFinal: Open refine and Excel (or equivalent spreadsheet editors) are two of the most useful tools for cleaning up open data
_incorrect.final: Open refine and Excel (or equivalent spreadsheet editors) are two of the most useful tools for cleaning up open data

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Open refine and Excel (or equivalent spreadsheet editors) are two of the most useful tools for cleaning up open data
_partlyCorrect.final: Open refine and Excel (or equivalent spreadsheet editors) are two of the most useful tools for cleaning up open data

title: Recognising errors
body: Which are the following are errors in data that require cleaning?

_feedback.correct: Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in messy data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being messy.

_incorrect.notFinal: Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in messy data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being messy.
_incorrect.final: Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in messy data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being messy.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in messy data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being messy.
_partlyCorrect.final: Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in messy data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being messy.

title: How much time should be spent cleaning and preparing data?
displayTitle: How much time should be spent cleaning and preparing data?
body: In any given data driven project, How much time should be spent cleaning and prepareing data?

_feedback.correct: vidence suggests that between 60% and 80% of a data projects time will be spent cleaning, transforming and preparing data for analysis.

_incorrect.notFinal: vidence suggests that between 60% and 80% of a data projects time will be spent cleaning, transforming and preparing data for analysis.
_incorrect.final: vidence suggests that between 60% and 80% of a data projects time will be spent cleaning, transforming and preparing data for analysis.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: vidence suggests that between 60% and 80% of a data projects time will be spent cleaning, transforming and preparing data for analysis.
_partlyCorrect.final: vidence suggests that between 60% and 80% of a data projects time will be spent cleaning, transforming and preparing data for analysis.

title: Summary
body:
Data cleaning is essential to ensure that when it is used, the right conclusions are made.

Not all errors are intentional and understanding the context in which the data was collected will help the cleaning process.

Be aware that cleaning may take longer than you think. A carefully executing cleaning process will however save substantial time in the long run.

Follow our data cleaning exercise to get started with Open Refine and discover how easy it is for yourself.

Get started with data cleaning in open refine.
